dataset.title: Long Term Aquatic Monitoring Program (LTAM) Site Verification Surveys, 2006-2017, in support of the Cedar River Watershed Habitat Conservation Plan for City of Seattle, Seattle Public Utilities, in King County, WA

abstract.para: This package contains site verification data for the Long Term Aquatic Monitoring (LTAM) program, in support of the Cedar River Watershed Habitat Conservation Plan for City of Seattle, Seattle Public Utilities, in King County, WA. A list of potential monitoring sites was generated in 2006, field verified 2006-2009, and used as a basis for other surveys through 2017. A total of (25) LTAM sites were selected.

The Geographic Randomized Tessellation System (GRTS) tool from the United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Environmental Monitoring and Assessment Program (EMAP) was used to generate the list of potential monitoring sites. The EMAP tool required using 1:100,000 scale hydrology and contour GIS layers from the United States Geological Survey (USGS), which were lower resolution than our own GIS data. Criteria specified in the tool included perennial streams of less than or equal to 4 percent. The low resolution of the EMAP tool required us to cross reference the site locations with our more accurate GIS data using other GIS tools (ArcMap). Many sites were rejected in-office because they were obviously too steep.

About 300 potential sites were generated from the EMAP tool, of which about 200 sites were rejected in-office, and about 100 sites were visited by observers to determine if the site was within a "response" reach type. The field verification requirements included overall stream gradient less than or equal to 4 percent, perennial stream flow, and not significantly influenced by bedrock, wetlands, or human made structures. The resulting (25) LTAM monitoring sites had heavy clustering in the Taylor Creek basin and Rock Creek basin.
Accepted sites and field rejected sites are included in the dataset. Sites rejected in-office are not included in the dataset.
For more detailed information on the LTAM program, refer to the LTAM Methods and Reports data package.

The consumer of these data ("Data User" herein) is required to cite it appropriately in any publication that results from its use. The Data User should realize that these data may be actively used by others for ongoing research and that coordination may be necessary to prevent duplicate publication. The Data User is urged to contact the authors of these data if any questions about methodology or results occur. Where appropriate, the Data User is encouraged to consider collaboration or co-authorship with the authors. The Data User should realize that misinterpretation of data may occur if used out of context of the original study. While substantial efforts are made to ensure the accuracy of data and associated documentation, complete accuracy of data sets cannot be guaranteed. All data are made available "as is." The Data User should be aware, however, that data are updated periodically and it is the responsibility of the Data User to check for new versions of the data. The data authors and the repository where these data were obtained shall not be liable for damages resulting from any use or misinterpretation of the data. Thank you.

contact.organizationName: City of Seattle, Seattle Public Utilities

description.para: The Geographic Randomized Tessellation System (GRTS) tool from the United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Environmental Monitoring and Assessment Program (EMAP) was used to generate a list of potential monitoring sites. The EMAP tool required using 1:100,000 scale hydrology and contour GIS layers from the United States Geological Survey (USGS). Criteria specified in the tool included perennial streams of less than or equal to 4 percent. The low resolution of the EMAP tool resulted in many sites that were too steep or several hundred feet from any stream. About 300 sites were generated from the EMAP tool.

The low resolution of the EMAP tool required us to cross reference the site locations with our more accurate GIS data using other GIS tools (ArcMap). Many sites were rejected in-office because they were obviously too steep, In addition, many sites were several hundred feet away from any stream and had to either be snapped to nearest stream or if not nearby any stream, the site was rejected. About 200 sites were rejected in-office.

methodStep.instrumentation: Mapping grade gps unit, clinometer, stadia rod graduated in hundredths of feet, fiberglass reel tape in feet, laser rangefinder, paper map, and compass.

description.para: About 100 sites were visited by observers to determine if the site was within a "response" reach type. The field verification requirements included overall stream gradient less than or equal to 4 percent, perennial stream flow, and not significantly influenced by bedrock, wetlands, or human made structures.

personnel.organizationName: City of Seattle, Seattle Public Utilities

abstract.para: This data is part of a long-term stream research program to measure the overall ecological response of the watershed to HCP management activities and to monitor stream health, document recovery from past water supply and land management operations, evaluate the success of stream habitat restoration projects, and help to identify any impacts of the City’s operations on stream ecosystems.

award.funderName: City of Seattle, Seattle Public Utilities
award.title: Long-term Stream Monitoring

dataTable.entityDescription: Site verification data for all (25) LTAM monitoring sites as well as field rejected sites for 2006-2017. Includes information on bankfull width and reach slope, and why a site was accepted or rejected as an official monitoring site.

attribute.attributeDefinition: Main Sorting No, a number that is used to order records for the purposes of loading data, grouping data, or building formulas.
Method, an abbreviation or acronym whereas the method is a group of methods for a project or program and is described in a separate document.

Year Site ID, a number that is used to group data and is a conjugate of the 4 digit Sample Year and Site No. For example, 20062 refers to Sample Year 2006, Site 2, and 201022 refers to Sample Year 2010, Site 22. If the analysis is a Enter "999" for
User Name, as downloaded from Pendragon Forms or other electronic form. Also, "999" refers to not applicable; and "-999" refers to data that is required but is missing.
Timestamp, Date or Date and Time for when the data was collected and in format MM/DD/YYY hh:mm:ss.

An approximate location that is relative to either A) the starting point, where the starting point is typically a GPS point and is referenced by channel widths (CW); or B) the end points and is referenced by bottom of unit (BOU) or top of unit (TOU). The location is usually abbreviated and can also be further referenced by either upstream (US) or downstream (DS), i.e.. US;20CW refers to 20 channel widths upstream from primary point, and US;BOU refers to upstream from bottom of unit.

The stream width at bankfull stage and where the bankfull width is "quickly" measured with an instrument such as rangefinder, stadia rod, or fiberglass reel tape and has no attached level. Bankfull stage is the water level in the stream just before the stream overtops its banks and floods. At least two good indicators are needed to confirm bankfull width such as permanent vegetation, slope break, sudden deposition of fines, or presence of sword fern. Note that willows, water lines on rocks, or moss lines on rocks are poor indicators of bankfull width and should not be used. Units are in feet.

The height of the eye level instrument. The instrument could be a hand level on top of a walking stick, an optical level on top of a tripod, or the height of a person's eye (where they are holding a clinometer) to the ground. Units are in feet.
Foresight Height, the stadia height reading when the level station has NOT moved from the previous reading. Units in feet.

The straight line distance of the stream channel slope. This can be measured by standing on a rock that is level to the water surface, using a rangefinder and selecting slope distance, and selecting a target that is approximately the same height in which the rangefinder is held. Another method is where two observers stand apart and on a rock that is level to the water surface with each person holding the end of a drag tape or fiberglass reel tape and at the same height from ground. Slope distance can also be estimated from a mapping exercise by calculating the distance between contours. Units are in feet.

Slope % is (rise/run)*100, where the rise and run are measured with instruments such as clinometer or eye level or optical level with stadia rod and drag tape or fiberglass reel tape. Slope % can also be estimated from a mapping exercise by calculating the rise and run between contours. Water surface or channel bottom needs to be specified, where this is typically specified in the distance type.

The range of clinometer slope % readings as indicated by the clinometer instrument. Measurements are taken at various locations, and the data is expressed as a text string with less than, greater than, or to (dash) symbols (ie. > 7, 5-7, <4, etc).
Comments, free form text for interesting or unusual sightings, problems, or issues.

Comments on why a site was rejected as a monitoring site. Common reasons for rejection are too much bedrock, non-perennial stream (ie. ephemeral), cross sections too wide, channel too steep, influenced by wetland, or influenced by human structure.

A randomized number that represents a potential monitoring site and was generated from a GIS mapping exercise. The Geographic Randomized Tessellation System (GRTS) tool from the United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Environmental Monitoring and Assessment Program (EMAP) was used to generate a list of potential monitoring sites. The EMAP tool required using 1:100,000 scale hydrology and contour GIS layers from the United States Geological Survey (USGS), which were lower resolution than our own GIS data. Criteria specified in the tool included perennial streams of less than or equal to 4 percent.
Site No, a number that has been assigned to the site, whereas the same site number is used for repeat surveys.
Stream Name (short), the abbreviated or shortened stream name of the site that is being surveyed.
The names or initials of each person who participated in the survey.
